2 Loritlicul om

 

February 19, 1987

The Honorable Mitch McConnell
United States Senate

120 Senate Russell Office Building
Washington, D.C. 20510

Dear Senator McConnell:

Thank you for your letter of February 12th regarding
Philip Morris' announcement of their suspension of
imports of burley and flue-cured tobacco for use in
their domestic cigarette blends along with your urging
Lorillard, Inc. to make the same announcement.

I think you are aware of the Lorillard resources
of time, energy, will and intellect committed to the
development of a market-oriented tobacco program that
the Tobacco Reform Act of 1985 finally realized. You
may not be aware, however, that from the moment of
those beginning discussions many months ago -- before
argument, before compromise, before draft legislation,
before the bill -- from that moment to this day,
Lorillard has acted in ways of complete consonance
with the spirit and the thrust of that legislation.
However, I can not characterize our plans, quantify
them, if you will, prospectively. There are both
historical and legal reasons I can not spell out for :
you our actions and plans even if by so doing business
benefits and political benefits would accrue to my
company .

ssesouze

LORILARO, NC.
{668 Fit Aranuo, Now York, Now York 10108

summary: The Honorable Mitch McConnell is a U.S. senator from Kentucky. He wrote a letter to Philip Morris and Lorillard, Inc. The letter was sent on February 19, 1987. It was part of a larger effort to stop imports of tobacco products from the tobacco giant. In the letter, McConnell said he could not characterize Lorard's plans prospectively.
